title: UK weather forecast cold front UK gale force winds cold temperatures met office forecast
story: In a sign the seasons are changing, Britons will experience wet and windy weather this weekend as temperatures nose-e and thick cloud cover dominates the outlook.The conditions will temporarily bring summer to a premature end, as gusts and rainfall sweep across the country.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: &ldquoIt will be a fine day for most in the south, but increasingly cloud and dampness pushes in during Friday across north western areas.He revealed the cloud and rainfall that had dominated the picture across the south east of England on Thursday would clear away quite quickly as we headed into Friday.                UK tsunami WARNING: Devon and Cornwall hit with alert - &lsquoworst-case...But the clearing of the cloud in the south east would, Mr McGivern explained, bring clearer skies and a cold front, which would usher in cooler air across the country.He said: &ldquoA few showers will continue across central and western Scotland and north west England and for Northern Ireland, we will see thicker cloud returning, with some rain for the west of the province.The weather expert ulged Friday would have a clear and bright start, but the cloudless skies would bring a fresh feel.He said: &ldquoCentral and eastern Scotland, much of England and Wales, will see sunny spells.UK weather forecast: Britons will experience wet and windy weather this weekend  (Image: WXCHARTS)UK weather forecast: wet and damp conditions are set to dominate the picture over the weekend (Image: )However, he cautioned quite quickly clouds would thicken across central and western Scotland, north west England, north Wales and Northern Ireland.He said: &ldquoAfter a sunny morning, the south and east will tend to cloud over during the afternoon.&ldquoRain sets in during the afternoon the wind picks up too so it is going to feel cool.But the meteorologist revealed, on a brighter note, in the far south east - which would cling on to some sunny spells - temperatures could reach as high as 23 degrees.UK weather forecast: festival-goers endure the wet weather at Watergate Bay (Image:  )UK weather forecast: a Wolverhampton Wanderers fan watches the rain at a match against Everton FC  (Image:  )                UK weather forecast map: When will tropical storm Ernesto PUMMEL UK?                Met Office forecast: 12-HOUR downpour to hit UK - Britain set for w...He said: &ldquoFurther north we have the thicker cloud pushing through and we have the winds picking up during Friday.Mr McGivern also warned of gales around north western coasts, which would transfer away towards the north of the mainland of Scotland and the northern isles.But northern parts of the UK would stay windy over Friday night and overall, he advised, the south would stay mostly dry and cloudy.The Met Office expert said: &ldquoAnd the legacy of this frontal system through central areas joins up to the next weather front in the northern Atlantic, which provides an awful lot of cloud cover through southern Scotland, northern England and parts of Northern Ireland as well.Mr McGivern explained the extensive cloud cover would result in a damp start to the weekend.However, conditions would be brighter further south and further north, he predicted.He said: &ldquoFurther south, winds will be much lighter, with a fair amount of warm sunshine, though patchy rain may affect western hills.Mr McGivern confirmed the gales in the far north of the UK would ease through the day, but that it would be a blustery day, peppered with showers.He said: &ldquoAnd then more rain moves through later on Saturday in northern districts.

story: Hurricane Lane is projected to strengthen as we head into the weekend (Image: NOAA)Hurricane Lane is the sixth hurricane of the 2018 Pacific season and is projected to cross into the central Pacific on Saturday.&nbspFormer Tropical Storm Lane formed far out in the East Pacific on Wednesday, August 15.Previously a cyclone, Lane strengthened into a hurricane over Thursday night and now has wind speeds of up to 75mph.&nbspAt 5pm Thursday HST (4am BST), Hurricane Lane was located about 1,540 miles west-southwest of the southern tip of Baja California, Mexico, or 1,780 miles east-southeast of Hilo, Hawaii.&nbsp                Tropical Storm Lane strengthening to a HURRICANE as it heads to HawaiiAccording to the National Hurricane Center (NHC), Hurricane Lane is moving towards the west-northwest, at a speed of 15mph.&nbspThe latest NHC advisory warns that strengthening is expected over the weekend.&nbspImages created by the NHC show the predicted path of the hurricane, which could brush Hawaii next week.In the 8.00pm PDT (4.00am BST) warning , the NHC said: &ldquoA motion between west-northwest and west is expected during the next few days, and Lane is forecast to cross over into the central Pacific basin on Saturday.&ldquoRapid strengthening is expected for the next 36 to 48 hours, and Lane is forecast to become a major hurricane by Saturday.Residents in Hawaii have been warned to keep aware of any alerts issued in relation to Hurricane Lane, which comes just a week after Hurricane Hector glanced off Hawaii's Big Island.The NHC intensity forecast suggests Lane&rsquos winds could increase to 125mph on Saturday.&nbspAfter the weekend, Lane is predicted to still be a major hurricane with sustained winds of 115mph.&nbsp                Foreign Aid budget WILL be used for disaster hit UK territories                 Japan weather: Tropical storm Leepi to SMASH southern Japan on Tues...Computer models predict that Lane may take a path similar to Hurricane Hector.&nbspThis would mean that the centre of the storm would keep south of the Hawaiian islands.&nbspShould the hurricane reach Hawaii, violent waves, strong winds and heavy rain would hit the islands.&nbspHurricane Hector caused similar conditions when it passed by Big Island on August 8.This NOAA map shows the predicted arrival of winds (Image: NOAA)It is currently hurricane season in the Pacific Ocean, with warm waters triggering storms (Image: )Derek Wroe, forecaster with the National Weather Service in Honolulu, said: &ldquoWarm ocean water is the fuel for hurricanes.He added: &ldquoExpect intensification at least into the weekend.&nbsp&ldquoBy midday Saturday, it should be approximately 1,000 miles southeast of the Big Island.

story: The magnitude 5.2 earthquake hit near Italy&rsquos eastern coastline, close to the city of Montecilfone in the Molise region.People ran from their homes after the shaking began, but early reports indicate there was only minor damage.The tremor could be felt as far away as Rome and Naples, according to data from the United States Geological Survey.The mayor of Montecilfone, Franco Pallotta, said on SkyTG24: Some old walls that were already in bad shape have collapsed, but there's no major damage.                Earthquake WARNING: Scientists to predict ODDS of tremors strikingPeople are alarmed. Thank God, I have no news of injuries.Italians recorded their experiences of the earthquake on earthquake monitoring website CSEM-EMSC.One resident living some 17km from the epicentre said: &ldquoI felt it very strong! Fear on the streets, everyone is on the street.Another said: &ldquoShort large shake. Was on the stairs and scrambled outside.Italy earthquake: A 5.2 magnitude tremor hit central Italy just days after a weaker 4.6 quake struck (Image: EPA)Footage posted on social media shows the moment ceiling lights in a house began to shake with the tremor.In another clip, people&nbspin the coastal town of Termoli can be seen gathering in a central square after the quake.Today&rsquos tremor is the second quake to hit the Molise region so far this week.On Tuesday, a 4.6 magnitude earthquake also struck near Montecilfone.Emergency services have rescued at least one woman in Montecilfone (Image: EPA)No damage was reported, but residents in the area reported feeling the earth move.In 2016, a major earthquake in central Italy claimed nearly 300 lives.The magnitude 6.2 tremor hit in the Accumoli area, some 75km southeast from the popular holiday city of Perugia.The historic town of Amatrice near the epicentre of the quake suffered severe damage as entire buildings collapsed under the violent shaking.

title: first part time jobs sun writers
story: The number of 16 to 17-year-olds taking part-time jobs has more than halved since 1997, dropping from 42 per cent to 18 per cent. It means young people are missing out on essential skills as they approach adulthood.GRANT ROLLINGS asked five Sun columnists what their first part-time jobs were and the valuable lessons they learned – from being polite to skiving.I ALWAYS had a summer job, usually it meant working full-time hours on my normal Saturday job as holiday cover. This was either in a boutique such as Chelsea Girl or in BHS, where I worked on the sweetie counter.I coped with the boredom by sneakily munching on the best chocolate sweets from the pick-and-mix. I also worked as a waitress in a trendy Glasgow eaterie during the holidays.All of these jobs gave me the most enormous respect for the men and women who toil for long hours, often dealing with unreasonable members of the public for too little pay and not much prospect of promotion.Working in the service industry taught me the power of a disarming smile, and proved that my old granny’s saying that “you get more in life from sugar than vinegar” could not be more true.Grumpy customers demanding refunds and diners moaning that they had been waiting too long for their main course were usually placated with a swift apology and a promise to sort things out.A major restaurant blunder could often be smoothed over with a free coffee or pudding.MY favourite summer job came in 1977. I was a traffic enumerator for Middlesbrough Council. That meant I spent all day counting cars. All the way up one side of Linthorpe Road, all the way back down the other.I had to write down all the number plates. In the end, I got a bit bored and spent the time hanging out at my mate’s T-shirt shop or Fearnley Records and made the numbers up, always remembering to have them end in the local codes of HN or (I think) XG. I hope the council thought it worthwhile.It was better than the glue factory, where I’d been very briefly working on a weighbridge. Foreman pressed a button and this vast door opened and thousands of rotting animal carcasses fell out. I can still smell it now, all these years later. I passed out — soft lad, you see.Or there was working the nightshift pricing cans of food and stuff in Hintons, the local convenience store. Every time I turned up, the manager would say, ‘Here he is, the poor man’s Rod Stewart’.A friend of mine, Mark, had a much better summer job.He was a Club 18-30 holiday rep. He shagged 21 girls in 25 days, which gave me my first story to sell to the national newspapers.MY first holiday job was in the summer of 1985 when I was 16 years old. I had already been turned down from working at Waitrose in Enfield Town on the basis I was “too glamorous”.That just goes to show how far we have come in such a short time. I have never set foot in a Waitrose since that day because I was beyond furious. Anyway, the job I did get was working in a hairdresser’s on Goodge Street in London.My journey involved three changes and about 14 stops every day. The job was meant to be answering the phone, sweeping up and generally helping out, but before the end of the first week I was running the till, the appointment system, cashing up and generally managing the place.The only thing I could not do was cut hair, but that didn’t stop me cutting my friends’ hair — with very mixed results, more bad than good — on the basis I worked in a hairdresser’s so they thought I should. I remember the liberating feeling of earning my own money, it gave me the greatest sense of independence, self-esteem and self-belief.I worked out I was actually good in a work environment, talking to people — for example, talking women into perms they didn’t want — being responsible, handling money and making a difference to my employer.The biggest transition we make in our lives is leaving education to go into the workplace, and summer jobs prepare you for this.I HAD dozens of summer jobs, from working as a scaffolder’s mate with a convicted murderer, who kept a pistol in the glove compartment of his Ford Escort, to donning a white suit and Geiger counter to carry out maintenance on the core of the main reactor at a nuclear power station.I learned a hundred things from each and every job, but it was working as a grocery assistant at my local supermarket that had the most impact.My best friend and I both got jobs there at the same time. He was a star performer at school, a brilliant academic, but he couldn’t take the pace and got fired after a couple of months.It was incredibly hard, repetitive work.The manager was an ex-Army major — very strict on haircuts, discipline and stealing.There was always the prospect of the Tannoy announcement “customer service one hundred”, which was code for a shoplifter having been spotted.All the male floor staff were required to assemble at till number one to tackle the suspect, who would sometimes become violent.I was much happier making the cheese look pretty and eventually became the ruler of the entire soft dairy aisle — a project I’m still working on.I WAS 13 in Brownes Wine bar, Stafford Street, Derby, summer 1987, some years before it burned down in mysterious circumstances (has a bar ever burnt down innocently?). I was chief bottler-up.This involved the soul-sapping exercise of sifting through bins taller than me for all the recyclable bottles from the previous night’s festivities and putting them in their correct crates. This took all morning and you ended up cut to shreds and stinking of Britvic and Schlitz.I was then asked to be the cook — this involved microwaving lasagne for drunk people. I was paid the princely sum of £3 per hour. I realised how crap this was, so one scorching Saturday I nicked the shampoo that came with my dad’s company car and took advantage of the sketchy Eighties attitude to drink-driving and washed all the customers’ cars in the car park for a fiver a pop.I literally cleaned up. It was the greatest Dragons’ Den moment I’ve ever had. I waxed on and off all day, rinsing my dad of his prized BMW product. He arrived to pick me up and I was minted. A 13-year-old with £64 in his pocket. That coveted Swatch would finally be mine.He then told me the dog had been run over, so that’s another memory ruined.Thanks for reminding me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn is unfit to be labour leader
story: His entire political career has been spent in close company with anti- Semites, terrorist sympathisers and extremists.So it shouldn’t be a surprise that he was pictured appearing to pay his respects to Black September, the terror group which murdered 11 Israelis and one German policeman at the Munich Olympics.That’s a group that not only killed in cold blood but tortured and brutalised their victims too.It is genuinely shocking that the Leader of the Opposition is so willing to lie about it. To say that he was “present but not involved” is an insult to voters’ intelligence when photographs show him holding a wreath and gurning for a nearby camera.To allow his press office to say the widows of those murdered in Munich were being “misled” is, even among the many shameful episodes we’ve seen since he became Labour leader three hate-filled years ago, disgraceful.The most vital qualification for power in this country must be integrity. And Jeremy Corbyn has demonstrated this week that he has absolutely none of it.But for all of the shame that he brings upon Labour, it is nothing compared to the spinelessness of the party’s “moderate” MPs whose opposition to Corbyn extends not much further than wishy-washy tweets.“Present but not involved” isn’t an excuse for Corbyn but nor is it for the cowards on Labour’s backbenches.Corbyn cannot be allowed near government. But the rest of the party has lost the public’s faith too.TOMORROW, official figures are likely to suggest that train fares will go up by another 3.5 per cent in January.If you’re a commuter who has put up with delayed and cancelled trains, you’ll be wondering what you’re paying for.After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rid harry and meghan turbulent
story: Most of the time, they make the Windsors seem a happy and (almost) normal bunch — no small feat.So why oh why is the Palace spin machine making such a spectacular mess with the Markles?Anybody with half a brain could tell, from the moment Prince Harry and Meghan started dating, that her family could turn into a royal pain in the neck.You’ve got a vengeful and jealous half-sister Samantha, who despises Meghan and has been briefing against her for more than a year.She is now telling hacks that she knows Harry and Meghan’s marriage won’t last, which is charming.Then you’ve got Thomas Markle, the dad, an eccentric character who is furious at being “locked out” of his daughter’s life.Barely a day goes by without Mr Markle hurling another negative headline across the Atlantic in the direction of his new son-in-law.Mr Markle insists that, contrary to official briefings, the rift between him and his daughter continues. He says he was told that he couldn’t speak at the wedding and that Harry berated him on the phone for mishandling the Press while he was recovering from a heart attack.The official royal response to these outbursts has been, effectively, to shove their fingers in their ears and shout la-la-la (or lah-lah-lah).The snobby courtiers and hangers-on dismiss Markle père as fame-hungry.That’s not altogether wrong — he is clearly desperate, as he proved by posing for snaps with the paparazzi in the run-up to the wedding.But it’s not good enough to wish he’d just go away.Meghan is now one of the most photographed and sought-after women in the world. Her very well-paid PR flunkies should have seen these familial landmines a mile off and defused them.But they have failed.Thomas Markle is a difficult and proud man, no doubt. But that is why he should have been treated with care, not frozen out.Why did Team Windsor not find him a role and approach him long before the wedding to make sure he didn’t feel excluded.It’s hard not to feel for him.His ex, Meghan’s mother Doria, was hailed as one of the stars of the wedding.Because she’s a black woman, she invited lots of gushing commentary about the monarchy becoming more diverse and modern.Amen to that. But poor old podgy Thomas, an awkward-looking white bloke, has been shunned from his daughter’s nuptials. You can’t blame him for speaking out.The royal courtiers enjoy the adulation the monarchy receives because Prince Harry has been “brave” enough to marry a woman with a complicated background.But the Palace spin machine freaks out when it comes to confronting the reality of Meghan’s parentage.Perhaps they just find it too vulgar.Harry’s PR man is Jason Knauf, an American specialist in “crisis management” having worked for Royal Bank of Scotland. He excels at sending angry letters to journalists he feels have gone too far snooping into Harry and Meghan’s private lives.But he doesn’t seem to have a clue as to how to handle his clients’ grumpy relatives.As a result, the monarchy is facing arguably its worst crisis since the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.We are often told how brilliant the Royal Family’s PR is. Part of the new royal spin, in fact, is about how great the royals now are at spin. They have “rebranded” the monarchy for the 21st century, and so on.Look at the blizzard of positive guff accompanying Prince William, Kate, and Harry’s campaign for mental illness last year.They were, it was said, making the younger Windsors seem more touchy-feely.At the moment, however, they don’t seem sensitive enough to speak to Meghan’s suffering in-laws.That’s not what you’d call a good look.The truth is, royal press officers have long got too much credit.The British admire the Queen because she is admirable.Overall, we prefer monarchy to any other system of government. That’s just common sense. It’s nothing to do with any ingenious branding and media strategy.The public also feels that the younger royals deserve a chance.At a time when our country is consumed by Brexit and political arguments, the wedding of Harry and Meghan came as a blessed relief — something we could all celebrate.The couple both came from broken homes, and nobody cared so long as they were happy. That’s all great.   But it’s obvious that Meghan has, as one royal expert put it, “background baggage that needs unpacking”.Insiders now say the treatment of the Markle family has been a “shambles”.This is before we consider the potential PR bombshells that could erupt if and when Meghan’s ex-husband, Trevor Engelson, decides to grant some interviews.The British don’t want to see the monarchy turned into a reality TV soap, as the Markles and Windsors wage a media war with each other.It’s trashy and embarrassing.But unless the Palace can tackle Meghan’s disgruntled kin, that’s exactly what is happening.Maybe we need a changing of the royal PR guard — before it’s too late.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: university isnt the only option for a level students
story: After two years of studying for A-levels, thousands of young people will find out if their hard work has paid off.Whether they’re aiming to start an apprenticeship, take a place at university, or go straight into a good job, there are plenty of opportunities awaiting them – and the prospects are high.The jobs market has transformed since 2010, with over 3.3 million more people in work – on average that’s over 1,000 more people in a job each and every day.And, since 2010, the majority of that employment growth has been in both full-time and permanent roles.Only yesterday, the latest official statistics showed that unemployment has fallen to 4% - which means it’s the lowest it’s been since the 1970s.To put that into context, someone would be well into their 50s today to remember a time of lower unemployment.And this transformation of the jobs landscape is being led by our young people. Yesterdays employment figures revealed that the proportion of young people unemployed (and not in full-time education) is now at a record low of 4.7% for our country - and far lower than for many other developed countries.It sends a significant message out about the drive and innovation of our young people, and the opportunities that our economy offers to them and their future.With our welfare changes this country can now be powered forward by this young generation.Since 2010, youth unemployment has fallen by over 45%, giving 130,000 more young people a job, and a future.Add the fact that wages are on the up and there are more than 829,000 vacancies nationwide, it’s clear that young people are entering the best jobs market in a decade.On average, the number of vacancies has increased by 4,280 each month over the last year, and those vacancies span from construction to technology.So when young people this week are deciding on their next steps, they can think big as there are plenty of opportunities out there for them, from a job with career progression, to taking up an apprenticeship.Look at Daisy, who turned down five university offers to work at global engineering firm JCB designing new equipment, and she didn’t have to go to university to get there.I’m forever being told, and intrinsically understand, that people want to study at different times in their lives, often inspired to do so when they see the practical benefits of their studies.That’s why so many people prefer, and do better, getting a job first and then studying for exams while they work.Even over the last few decades, how the world of education and work are linked has shifted dramatically. People no longer have one job for life, and lifelong learning is becoming more and more commonplace as people dip in and out of education.Many more people up-skill and retrain throughout their career – and this is how the future jobs market will remain vibrant and strong.And when I speak to employers up and down the country, from manufacturers to marketers, what they want are young people with the right attitude, prepared to work and learn. As they say, ‘if you’ve the will, we can give you the skill’.So when young people this week are deciding their next steps, the academic route isn’t the only option.You can now become a solicitor, an accountant or even a nuclear engineer through the apprenticeship route, earning as you learn and without the cost of going to University. Studying a Higher Apprenticeship gives an average wage boost of £150,000 over a working life.When I speak to young people around the country, I’m impressed with the confidence and self-assuredness with which they look to the future, and the range of options they consider beyond traditional routes.Im certainly no job snob. Life teaches you its not where you come from, its where you get to, and work is exactly the same.You can start anywhere and get to the top as Im repeatedly being told by our countrys top entrepreneurs.Top performers in their fields such as Debbie Moore, Jean-Christophe Novelli, Deborah Meaden and Jo Malone, did not go to university and are just a handful of the individuals who show that with drive and determination you can succeed by treading your own path.Its all about getting a break and taking the opportunities that come your way.So best of luck to everyone today, but whatever your results, there are many opportunities and pathways into a successful career.    Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bridge italy mafia weakened cement
story: Tuesday’s disaster was the tenth bridge to collapse in Italy in the last five years alone, and anti-Mafia campaigners in the country are warning that hundreds of schools, hospitals and airports may also be at risk of collapse.That’s because the Mafia saves money by using a cement which is “cut” with sand, vastly reducing its strength.It’s called, in Italian, “cemento depotenziato” or “weakened cement”. It’s like trying to put up shelves using sellotape.And that matters because Italy’s various mafias – Cosa Nostra (our thing) in Sicily, the ‘Ndrangheta in Calabria and the Camorra in Naples – are all experts at winning building contracts.And their hold doesn’t stop there.Match-fixing and ticket sales in football, waste disposal agreements as well as drug and people smuggling have all been lucrative streams of income for the underworld gangs.The system has been the same for decades: politicians receive votes and kickbacks from criminal gangs who are awarded the contracts from huge construction projects.Many people who have interfered in rigged tender processes, like Vincenzo Passiarello in 1998, have been killed.Long gone are the Hollywood stereotypes of a thug with a tommy gun and a trilby. Nowadays most mafiosi wear suits and are indistinguishable from ordinary businessmen.The only difference is the size of their empires.The scale of the corruption is so great that 281 town or city councils have been dissolved by Italian authorities since 1991 because of Mafia infiltration.Often that infiltration only emerges after years of painstaking surveillance by the the Italian police.Construction appeals to the Mafia because the huge sums involved enable the laundering of dirty drugs money.The many sub-contracts mean that a criminal gang can find itself hugely empowered, responsible for the hiring and firing of thousands of workers at a time when youth unemployment in Italy bounces around 30 per cent.Costs are kept low not just through the use of poor building materials but also through strong-arm management: unions are invariably excluded from work sites, and safety inspectors intimidated or bought off.It takes a brave man or woman to point out the Mafia’s shoddy workmanship.There are, experts say, many more councils where criminal infiltration still hasn’t been discovered.One of the main advantages of infiltrating the construction industry is that it enables the Mafia to disguise itself as a legitimate, respectable business. Since the mid-1990s – when the Mafia planted bombs on the Italian mainland and blew up Sicilian investigators – it has deliberately pursued a strategy of invisibility.As one of Italy’s anti-Mafia priests said recently: “the Mafia is very able to camouflage itself, to infiltrate into legal spaces.”In 2010, anti-Mafia investigators confiscated €1.5billion (around £1.35 billion) from Cosa Nostra’s current “don of dons”, the fugitive Matteo Messina Denaro. Much of that figure was linked to construction firms.Although it’s often the cause of disasters, the Mafia is also the beneficiary of them.Each time a devastating earthquake hits the country, criminal gangs move in on the reconstruction efforts.Franco Roberti, for four years head of Italy’s anti-Mafia directorate, told La Repubblica newspaper this week: “The risk of infiltration is always high. Post-earthquake reconstruction is a tasty morsel for criminal organisations and business interests.”The worry now is that hundreds of structures throughout Italy could be at risk.Legambiente, an anti-Mafia pressure group, has warned that weakened cement has been used at Trapani and Palermo airports in Sicily, as well as in schools, car parks, bridges and motorways throughout the peninsula.Back in 2009, in a situation eerily similar to this week’s bridge collapse, 37 people lost their lives during flash floods in the Sicilian city of Messina. Buildings simply collapsed in the rain because inadequate cement had been used in the construction of houses.Construction is only one of the Mafia’s revenues streams. Drug-dealing still represents a cash-cow, but in recent years criminal gangs have also made huge amounts from the exploitation of migrants: one wiretap from 2014 overheard a Rome mafiosi saying to a colleague: “do you have any idea how much one can earn through immigrants? Drug-trafficking yields less.”Apart from drugs- and people-smuggling, the Mafia is also adept at siphoning off European Union funding. The murder of the Slovakian journalist, Ján Kaliac, earlier this year is believed to have been a professional hit carried out because he was investigating Italian businessmen from Calabria who were embezzling EU funds.The other big-earner for criminal gangs is waste disposal. Here, like construction, it’s easy to make money if corners are cut.And through messing with rubbish collection – leaving it rotting on street corners at the height of the summer heat and the tourist season – organised criminals are able to hold cities hostage, making demands for contracts to be renegotiated.Not even Italy’s favourite sport is immune from the Mafia. Match-fixing in football is frequent in Italy, especially in the lower leagues.Every year or two there’s a scandal when it emerges that betting syndicates have made huge profits after bribing players to chuck games: The most recent case was in 2011, when dozens of teams and players colluded to arrange results, taking money from, and making it for, organised crime.The Mafia has even attempted to muscle in on the huge money to be made from ticket sales.In 2016 investigators in Turin discovered that the Calabrian Mafia, the ‘Ndrangheta, was procuring free tickets from Juventus in order to sell them on at huge profits: ticket-touting was estimated to yield €30,000 on match day.Ciccio Bucci, the man caught in the middle between Juventus and the Calabrian mafia, committed suicide in suspicious circumstances the day after being questioned by investigators.After Tuesday’s tragedy, infrastructure is now at the top of the Italian political agenda. If the taps are turned on again, you can be sure that the people who caused the problems will be offering, once again, to solve them.Tobias Jones lives in Parma. He is writing a book on Italian football.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: gravestone monmouth word puzzle john renie
story: Experts believe Welshman John Renie carved his own tombstone as a way of confusing the devil.Renie lived in Monmouthshire in the 1800s and died, aged 33, on May 31, 1832.His resting place is marked with what looks like some giant wordsearch puzzle, made up of 285 letters.At first glance it just looks like a random jumble of letters but the key is to start with the H in the centre and then move in any direction - except diagonally - then the message should quickly become clear.According to Find a Grave, there are 46,000 ways of spelling out the message Here lies John Renie.The writer and cleric  Lionel Fanthorpe has suggested that Renies intention may have been to confuse the devil, so ensuring him his passage to heaven.The grave is, apparently, something of an attraction at St Marys Priory Church in Monmouth, with visitors often trying to work out what it says.Renies body though no longer lies below as the stone was moved from its original position.The grave was Grade II listed in 2005, along with the memorial to Charles Heath, who died in 1831.Heath was a mayor of Monmouth and a local historian as well as antiquarian.

title: man shone laser ferry facing trial
story: Christopher Lee, 21, is accused of aiming the beam into the bridge of P&ampO’s cross-Channel vessel The Spirit of France last March.He denies unlawfully and intentionally seriously interfering with the operation of a ship.The ferry’s captain and first mate are likely to give evidence at the three-day hearing, set for January.Lee, of Dover, was granted unconditional bail until the trial.Canterbury crown court was not told where he had been standing, or how far away from the ferry, when the alleged offence took place.Lee is charged under the Aviation and Maritime Security Act of 1990. Last month a new Laser Misuse (Vehicles) Act came into force which will mean offenders facing “much tougher penalties” of up to five years in prison, an unlimited fine or both.Announcing its enactment, Aviation Minister Baroness Sugg said: “Lasers, used recklessly, can have very serious, potentially fatal consequences.”Lee is not charged under this law.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hajj mecca muslims islam pilgrimage
story: Over a million more Muslims are expected to make the journey this year as Muslims gather from all around the world.Those visiting the holy city between August 19-24 have also been warned to be vigilant about the possible threat of terrorism.The five day pilgrimage is the worlds largest single gathering of people and this year begins on the evening of August 19.Hajj takes place from the 8th to the 12th of Dhu al-Hijja which is the final and the holiest month in the Islamic calendar.The Hajj is one of the five pillars of Islam and seen as a sacred duty that must be undertaken at least once - although exceptions are made for financial hardship and ill health.Muslims are given special clothes called Ihram to wear, which are simple, white garments that are supposed to make Muslims appear equal – regardless of wealth or status – before Allah.Sex, smoking, swearing and disagreements are among the things banned during the pilgrimage.Once in Mecca, Muslims perform the Tawaf, which is when they move counter-clockwise seven times around the Kaaba, a small shrine in the centre of the Grand Mosque.The tradition dates back to the prophet Ibrahim - known as Abraham to Jews and Christians - who built Kaaba at Islam’s most sacred Mosque.Pilgrims then walk or run between the mountains of Safa and Marwah seven times, which represents when Ibrahim’s wife Hagar did the same when searching for water.On the second day of Hajj, Muslims head to Mount Arafat to stand in vigil, which is the location where Prophet Muhammad is said to have given his last sermon.At the start of the Eid al-Adha feast, Muslims then take part in stoning ceremonies, where they toss pebbles at walls to represent the symbolic stoning of the devil.Sheep are also slaughtered to give meat to the needy, and men and women trim their hair.The word “Hajj” means “to intend a journey”, which represents the physical distance Muslims travel, but also internal battles overcome.

title: italy earthquake 5 3 magnitude central region
story: Popular holiday areas in the central region of Molise have been hit by a 5.3 magnitude quake.The quakes epicentre was in the eastern-coastal Italian city Montecilfone, 160 miles east of Rome.Initial reports suggest the quake has only caused minor damage, but that residents have been told to evacuate their homes.The citys mayor said the locals were left terrified, and many have opted to flee.Some old walls that were already in bad shape have collapsed, but theres no major damage, Franco Pallotta said on SkyTG24.People are alarmed. Thank God, I have no news of injuries.Slight damage to some buildings had been spotted.Emergency teams have cordoned off some streets amid fears of aftershock tremors.Earlier this year, a 4.7 magnitude tremor rocked the Marche region of Italy.Schools were forced to close and trains cancelled.The same region suffered a massive loss of life in 2016 after being struck by a 6.2 magnitude quake on August 24.

title: postman india sacked dumping letters
story: Jagannath Puhan was suspended as the branch postmaster at the Odhanga post office in the eastern state of Odisha, this week after an inquiry found him “guilty of negligence and dereliction of duty”.The undelivered mail was discovered by a group of schoolchildren piled up in an abandoned school building that had been used as the post office branch until a few days ago.“We have managed to salvage over 1500 letters in two days,” postal superintendent Sarbeswar Mishra said.“But more than half of 6,000 letters that Puhan did not deliver have either turned soggy or eaten by termites and cannot be delivered at all.”Mr Puhan, who joined the post office in 1979 and took on the additional duty of postmaster in 2004 when his predecessor retired, had “committed gross dereliction of duty as well as breach of trust”, the official said.He was tasked with delivering mail on his bicycle in a 3km radius around the post office for most of that time.Mr Mishra said he had been clever in choosing which mail not to deliver.“While he delivered the registered letters, money orders, speed posts and (government ID) cards, for which record has to be maintained, he seems to have chucked ordinary letters as no such records are maintained,” he said.“Since there were no official complaints, we had no way of knowing what was going on.”According to The Indian Express, the undelivered mail included official notices, applications for public service entrance examinations, job and university acceptance letters, and even letters addressed to the local MP.“I personally noticed a letter from the Indian Navy dated 2011 for a local boy who had applied to them,” one post office employee said.Mr Puhan admitted to dumping several letters in an abandoned room in the school building, but blamed health problems.“For several years I could not walk properly and was not in a condition to deliver these letters,” he told The Hindustan Times.In 2013, an Australia Post mailman pleaded guilty to theft after being discovered with nearly 10,000 undelivered letters in his bedroom.Mark Baguio admitted he had been “too lazy” to deliver the mail.He was caught after a mail delivery bag containing 755 letters was found dumped in a rubbish bin outside his Melbourne flat. A version of this story first appeared on News.au

title: benidorm hols gran spanish truth
story: Freda Jackson went public with her disaster fortnight in Poseidon Playa and demanded a full refund from tour operator Thomas Cook.The 81-year-old pensioner from Blackburn, Lancs, was quoted saying: The hotel was full of Spanish holidaymakers and they really got on our nerves because they were just so rude.One evening a Spanish guy nearly knocked me flying and he just walked off without even apologising.Her comments provoked a huge backlash among Spanish locals, who accused her of trying to get a freebie holiday.But Freda, who was travelling with a 61-year-old friend, has described the reaction against her as disgusting and a pack of lies.Speaking to , she said: I never said the Spanish should go to another hotel, just that the hotel didnt cater to English people. Its been totally taken out of context.Now people who dont even know me are calling me racist which is just not true.I didnt slag the Spanish off at all.Freda claimed shed asked for a hotel in Benidorms new town on the ground floor that was close to shops.But instead she says they were given a hotel on a hill in the old town which was far from everything.The pensioner, who worked as a carer and auxiliary nurse for most of her life, said she had never complained about a holiday before but said this was one was a disaster from start to finish.Their flights were changed with less than a weeks notice, and Freda, who suffers from mobility issues, struggled to get up to the 14th floor rooms they were given.Her companion added: It wasnt the holiday we expected but Fredas comments were exaggerated out of all proportion.Freda is a lovely woman. Its upsetting and it makes me angry the way shes been treated. People have just been laughing at her.And now there have been threats made against her online. Its out of order. Theyve made a laughing stock of her.The hotel itself said that Jackson had only made one complaint about the location of her room, which was changed at her request.A Thomas Cook spokesman said: “Due to a system error Ms Jackson was not informed of a change to her flights until six days before departure.We are very sorry for the inconvenience this caused and are investigating to make sure it doesn’t happen again.We have offered Ms Jackson and her travel companion a gesture of goodwill to try and put things right which we hope she will accept.”

title: we are finally showing brussels we can go it alone after brexit and not before time
story: The publication of “technical notices” outlining how life will continue more or less as normal if the EU refuses to do a deal with Britain for petty political reasons is a crucial boost to our negotiating hand.Compare this grown-up approach to what Brussels and some European leaders have been up to recently.The EU has accused MI6 of bugging our Brexit talks. And our “ally” across the Irish Sea, the rent-a-quote Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, is threatening to ground our planes the day we leave.The silly season is coming to an end but it seems only Britain is getting serious.There is still much to do if, as we suspect, Brussels has no interest in negotiating in good faith. They are so terrified by the collapse of their project, thanks to unrest everywhere from Italy to Poland, that they’re willing to make themselves poorer as a result.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab must get his department moving quicker and force other parts of government to speed up their preparation.But we are finally showing we can go it alone. Not before time.AMAZON appear to be launching another front in their all-out war to take over just about every bit of our lives, with plans for a comparison site.This doesn’t fill us with excitement. After all, in recent days we’ve learnt that Brits are being charged over the odds for their Prime subscriptions, a service which itself has been shown not to deliver on its “next day” promises.We’ve no problem with competition or businesses doing well. Good companies with good profits create good jobs.But they must play by the rules, especially when other firms — such as high street retailers — are struggling.It is still staggering to us that Amazon’s UK tax bill FELL last year despite it almost tripling its profits.The Chancellor must close the costly loopholes that tech giants continue to exploit.WE’RE saying a little prayer for the Queen of Soul.Aretha Franklin redefined the music landscape, her songs influencing everybody from Luther Vandross to Adele.But she also raised huge amounts of money for the civil rights struggle in the US, doing it not for publicity but because she believed in it.Her extraordinary take on Otis Redding’s Respect became an anthem not just for African Americans but for feminists the world over.Rest in peace.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather heatwave storm ernesto
story: Forecasters say a change in the jet stream could see scorching temperatures across the country and humid conditions in the south.But the Met Office warns theres a huge uncertainty as the weather system could also go the other way and theres a possibility of more unsettled and rainy conditions.Meteorologist Aidan McGivern says computer simulations are showing a big ridge in the jet stream, rippling across North America, the north Atlantic and then towards the UK.In his 10-day forecast for the Met Office, he explained: “If we end up on the south of this ridge we will have similar weather to what we had earlier in the summer – the heatwave, the dry, the heat, the high pressure.“But if we end up for the north of the jet stream we will end up with very unsettled weather.“So huge uncertainty in terms of whether the weather will stay fairly changeable and mixed over the next ten days or whether towards the end of next week that jet stream will just become very amplified and the weather patterns will become stuck once again.”But before then, Brits will have to put up with the tail-end of subtropical Storm Ernesto, which is currently tearing through the Atlantic and is set to divide Britain when it arrives on Saturday night.By the time it reaches the UK it will no longer be classed as a storm however it will still bring 30mph winds and an inch of rain.It will batter parts of the Northern Ireland, Scotland, Wales and South West England - while others will bask in 26C sunshine this weekend.Mr McGivern said: There are two areas of low pressure – one of them comes from the other side of the world and there’s one that comes from the subtropics.It’s important it comes from the subtropics for three reasons - one, these things are difficult to predict because they are small bundles of energy and they can throw a spanner into the works.Exactly where and when it will provide rainfall for the UK on Saturday is open to doubt at the moment.But what looks most likely is that Saturday will start off dry there will be some sunshine and it will stay largely dry in the south and the east.But further north and west the cloud will thicken towards the end of the day.Saturday night will end up with some wet weather for southern Scotland, northern England, north Wales and northern Ireland, and that will slowly clear away at the start of Sunday.He continued: Another reason the subtropical lows are important is because they contain a lot of humidity – that translates on Sunday as a lot of cloud cover across the country.We will see some breaks and plenty of fine weather in the south and where we see some sunshine, temperatures could just jump up to 27C.So it will feel humid and very warm and even in the north, once that rain clears, theres low 20s for Scotland and Northern Ireland. That humid air also pushing the jet stream to the north into the start of next week.A lot of fine weather as we begin Monday but further weather systems push in later across northern parts of Britain, so mixed weather here, high pressure close to the south on Monday and Tuesday.A spokesman for forecasting service Meteogroup added: On Friday, it will be wet in the northern half of the country and Wales, elsewhere it will remain drier, particularly in the east where there will also be more in the way of sunshine.Winds will be brisk from the south west, but strong over Scotland and Northern Ireland. Saturday will be a drier day for many areas, with just a scattering of showers, these mainly in the west.The best of the widespread sunshine will be during the latter part of the day and winds will tend to ease as the day progresses.

title: students a level results day 2018 boozy night out
story: But after a tense day some went a little too hard as students from across the UK headed out to toast all their efforts.The youngsters had anxiously waited to find out if they had got into their chosen unis before nervously ripping open their results envelope.It was revealed yesterday pass rates today dropped to their lowest level in eight years following a shake-up which made the exams tougher for pupils.But it wasnt all bad news as some of the higher achievers were seen jumping for joy - as more than one in four of yesterdays exam results being an A or A*.Earlier in the day they had been pictured posing with their parents as they proudly revealed their success.And as night fell groups of young and ecstatic revellers poured into the bars and clubs across the country.But many were seen taking things slightly too far in their excitement, with a number seen slumped on the floor or being propped up by their pals.Boys continue to outperform girls at the highest grades, figures show, with 26.6 per cent of boys entries awarded at least an A grade, compared to 26.2 per cent for entries from their female peers.And in total, 26.4 per cent of UK entries were given one of the two top grades - up 0.1 percentage points on 2017.It is the second year in a row that the A*-A pass rate has risen, as the overall A*-E pass rate has also fallen 0.3 percentage points to 97.6 per cent - the lowest level since 2010.The figures come in the wake of a major exams overhaul - with24 A-level subjects now reformed.There have been major changes to A-levels in England, with a move away from coursework and modular exams throughout the course.Students who havent got the results they hoped for can try their luck through clearing.The process works by helping students find out what university courses still have places remaining.Hopefuls are able to search for a course against the subject they are interested in, or the university they want to head to.

title: why the time has come for the beeb to stop believing in the cult of jeremy corbyn
story: No? Well, you must have been getting your news from the BBC, then.This was the latest example of Corbyn simpering around terrorists. Honouring scumbags who massacred 11 Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics in Munich.The Black September gangsters castrated their male victims while they were still alive.But then, Corbyn was happy to attend the funerals of dead IRA terrorists. That’s the kind of chap he is. Actually, I say that was the “latest” case of Corbyn simpering around terrorists.Not quite. A day or two later a photo emerged of him giving the salute of the Muslim Brotherhood, a foul organisation proscribed as terrorists in six countries.And it’s all part of the anti-Semitism scandal which is tearing the Labour Party apart. An important story.Good people have left Labour as a consequence. The Jewish community in the UK is in uproar.Frightened of the far Left’s support for vile Islamists and its loathing of Israel and its right to exist.Scared of the morons who now lead Labour and its retinue of lefties who have said the most appalling, racist, stuff about Jews.Jeremy Corbyn, a genuine halfwit, thinks it is all “fake news”.He rolls his eyes when asked about it and gives different answers every time he is questioned.And guess who agrees with him? Yep, the BBC.The corporation refused to touch the story for a whole day, when it was first reported by blogger Guido Fawkes. Ignored it.Everyone else — including the left-wing  — thought it important.Instead, the front page of the BBC’s online news carried no fewer than SIX stories about former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and the allegations of Islamophobia made against him. Six!Boris had likened women who wear the burka to letter boxes or bank robbers.The vast majority of the country agreed that he wasn’t being racist. The vast majority want the burka banned here — as it is in Denmark, France, parts of Germany, Belgium and . . . Morocco.His comments were not much of a story at all. And the moves to sanction him solely a case of his enemies in the Conservative Party gleefully hammering the bloke.But the BBC became obsessed by it. It is always obsessed when the word Islamophobia is mentioned.And it loves to stick the boot into the Tories. Yet was utterly silent on the latest example of anti-Semitism in the Labour Party.It took them a full day to even mention the story.It’s another shocking case of the BBC’s bias. A left-liberal prejudice which runs right through the corporation from top to bottom.The same prejudice you hear whenever it deals with immigration (bloody marvellous!) or Brexit (absolutely ghastly!).Haven’t we had enough of this? Enough of paying £150.50 every year to have these credulous dupes pipe liberal propaganda into our homes every day.Get rid of the licence fee. Let the BBC survive through the subscriptions of those who are willing to pay. And on that deal, I’m out, Evan.Heres a photo of Rhian Sugden dressed as a plum.I’ve included it this week so that Tess Daly can enjoy it.Her husband, the uniquely interesting Vernon Kay, had a long sexting relationship with Rhian, apparently.And Tess was a bit hacked off.So maybe this will cheer her up.I’m on a diet. One of those low-carb things. God it’s boring.My favourite kinds of food are fat and carbohydrates, preferably mixed together.At night I dream of mashed potato and steak and kidney pudding.How can people enjoy life on a diet of bloody stir-fry?And the worst thing is it doesn’t seem to have done much for my weight. I still look like a pregnant middle-aged lesbian in a Boris Johnson wig.If the pounds don’t fall off soon I’m going to give it up. And BINGE.There’s a restaurant round my way that does a chicken parmo with a pizza on top.That’s where I’ll be heading.Freda Jackson, aged 81, did not enjoy her holiday and is demanding that the tour company refund her the full cost.Freda went on holiday to Spain and found herself surrounded by Spaniards...who wouldnt complain?Her complaint? The hotel she was staying in was “full of Spaniards”. Well, fair enough. They can be annoying. They get over-excited and spoil everyone’s fun.Where was Freda on holiday? Spain. Freda thinks she should have been warned about the possibility of being surrounded by Spaniards in Spain.She added that they should go “somewhere else” for their holidays.Brits are flooding to Turkey to take advantage of the crashing lira. You can get a holiday for two-fifths of nowt, apparently.All well and good. But you would have to pay me a lot of money to go anywhere near Turkey.The reason it’s cheap is because the moron who runs the place, Recep Erdogan has wrecked the economy. And there will be big trouble there soon.Fancy a change in your career plans? There’s a new job just come available – head of the Islamic State.The post is open to male psychopaths with very large beards. Must be able to scream “Allahu Akbar” in a very menacing manner. Salary negotiable.Small print at the bottom probably says: “The Islamic State is not an equal opportunities employer. So, no women, gays or Jews, please.”This job has come up because the previous leader, Abu Bakr al Baghdadi (Bob Baghdad to his mates) got hit in a drone strike. According to the Islamic State, he is now brain-dead. Hmmm. How could they tell?A year or so back I was in a minicab at night on my way home when we approached the level crossing near my house.The gates were open and the driver, a foreign bloke, drove into the middle, stopped and said: “Sorry, left or right?” I looked at him to see if he was joking.He wasn’t. I said: “I would go straight on if I were you.“This what we, in this country, call a ‘railway line’.” I assume it’s his wife, then, who was caught driving her car along the Newcastle  this week.And only noticed she was actually on a railway when she pulled up at a station.An art student decided to do something about the bright light coming in through her window.There are a number of solutions, aren’t there?Curtains, for example. Or maybe some nice blinds.But nope, instead she covered her window with a painting. It was called Double Anal Penetration and was quite, um, graphic.The neighbours kicked up a bit of a fuss.There was also the suggestion the police could be called. The student’s name, incidentally? Lucy Briscoe-Rimmer. No kidding, love.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: company controlling genoa bridge must pay to rebuild it says government
story: In a statement, the Italian transport ministry said Autostrade must prove it carried out required work to ensure the proper functioning of the bridge and avoid accidents.If Autostrade is found to have breached its terms it can be fined up to 150 million euros.Deputy Prime Minister Luigi Di Maio warned the state would have to take over the country's motorways if concession-holders could not do the job properly.Stories of miraculous escapes by survivors have begun to emerge, including the case of a man who hung on to the side of the bridge for hours.Meanwhile, the stories of those who lost their lives when the bridge collapsed have also begun to be told.

title: elon musk reveals excruciating year for tesla and says worst yet to come for himself
story: Mr Musk, who is dating Canadian singer Grimes, 30, last week caused havoc in the markets after tweeting, in the middle of the night, that he hoped to take the publicly traded company private.That tweet, with the fateful words "funding secured" and prices would be "at $420", kicked off a federal investigation as it could be seen as manipulating the marketplace and it turns out the Saudi government had spoken to him about funding but had parted with no cash yet.His board has told him to focus on production rather than Twitter, especially after he called a cave diver rescuing the Thai football team a "paedo guy". Known for being extremely ambitious with his ideas, the South African has been one of Silicon Valley's most influential entrepreneurs for two decades.But the limelight is eventually taking its toll, with Mr Musk admitting he works 120 hour weeks and has not taken more than a week off since 2001 - when he had malaria.He also emotionally revealed he spent his entire 47th birthday on 28 June at work."All night - no friends, nothing," he said.Two days after that he was best man at his brother, Kimbal Musk's, wedding in Catalonia where he flew from the factory to arrive two hours before the ceremony.He said he flew straight back after the wedding to Tesla's headquarters to make good on his promise to get those Model 3s out - something he eventually achieved on 1 July."I thought the worst of it was over - I thought it was," he said."The worst is over from a Tesla operational standpoint."But from a personal pain standpoint, the worst is yet to come."Mr Musk said he blames his stress on short-sellers who bet Tesla's shares will lose value if it goes private.He said he is bracing for "at least a few months of extreme torture from the short-sellers, who are desperately pushing a narrative that will possibly result in Tesla's destruction".On short-sellers, he said: "They're not dumb guys, but they're not supersmart. They're OK. They're smartish." Mr Musk admitted to taking the sleeping pill Ambien, saying: "It is often a choice of no sleep or Ambien."However, some board members have said it does not help him sleep but contributes to his late-night Twitter sessions, which often get him in trouble.Mr Musk said, there is an ongoing search to find a deputy to help him, but "to the best of my knowledge" it is not active at the moment.But, people familiar with the search said it escalated after Mr Musk's tweets about taking the company private and the cave diver.

title: government must stop overlooking 95 less harmful e cigarettes say mps
story: The MPs are calling for the government to consider risk-based regulation to allow more freedom to advertise e-cigarettes as the relatively less harmful option for nicotine addicts.The report follows a statement by Public Health England earlier this year in which the health officials called for more tolerance for e-cigarette users and for hospitals to provide patients with vaping lounges. They also said that the government should provide financial incentives in the form of lower levels of taxation for smokers to swap from cigarettes to less harmful alternatives such as e-cigarettes.In addition, the government should reconsider how e-cigarettes are used in public places and as a therapy by the NHS.They also said the government should look again at regulations limiting e-juice refill strengths and tank sizes which were brought in by the EU."Concerns that e-cigarettes could be a gateway to conventional smoking, including for young non-smokers, have not materialised. If used correctly, e-cigarettes could be a key weapon in the NHS's stop smoking arsenal."E-cigarettes are a proven stop smoking tool and, while uncertainties undoubtedly remain about their long-term health impact, failing to explore the use of e-cigarettes could lead to the continued use of conventional cigarettes - which currently kill around 79,000 people in England every year."Medically licensed e-cigarettes would make it easier for doctors to discuss and recommend them as a stop smoking tool to aid those quitting smoking. The approval systems for prescribing these products must be urgently reviewed."The percentage of people smoking among those with mental health conditions remains stubbornly high, while it is declining in the general population. People with mental health conditions are almost 2.5 times more likely to smoke compared to the general population.
